Description: Fragment of lid of Chian black-figured Sphinx and Lion Style pottery stemmed bowl; interior: reserved with only traces of paint on edge; exterior slipped: black-figure decoration consisting of lion (only foreleg remaining) to right; part of incised rising rosette as filling ornament; at edge, two narrow bands and frieze of squat rays; on edge of rim, short vertical strokes.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Greco-Roman Museum, Alexandria. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
Lions are traditionally depicted facing right on Sphinx and Lion Style pots. Venit identifies the sherd as coming from a pyxis lid, however, the shape is not typical of this Chian style.
Bibliographic references: Venit 1988 / Greek Painted Pottery from Naukratis in Egyptian Museums (p. 38, no. 140, pl. 34)
Lemos 1991 / Archaic Pottery of Chios. The Decorated Styles (p. 316, no. 1360, pl. 175)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GD.2106) (phase 2)
